Without any improvements in the software or the mathematics, in 4 years it should cost less than 15k to buy hardware to be able to keep up proving current Ethereum average blocks of 18 million gas.

The last few years blockchains created too much blockspace. ZK is about to make  blockspace virtually free. This will make tokens of multiple projects go lower in the short term. Long term it will enable to have applications that can't be built right now on top of blockchains since they are too slow. It's also about to make interoperability a easy and cheap.

My partners at @alignedlayer have created a webpage called ZK Benchmarks. A few days ago, I shared it, but now we've added several more results, and the results are fully reproducible with a Jupyter Notebook.

We are adding every RISC-V zkVM, proving different examples, and comparing them. We already have @brevis_zk Pico, @SuccinctLabs SP1, and @RiscZero proving Fibonacci, Keccak, and Reth. In the short term, we will be adding @NexusLabs, @0xPolygon's Zisk, and hopefully @0xLita.

Here, you can see that with more or less 30 A6000 GPUs, which cost a total of 150k or 5k each, you can prove the current average block of @ethereum that has 18 million gas. This equates to Ethereum consistently doing above 50 TPS. So, with just one payment equal to less than the yearly salary of an engineer in San Francisco, you can keep up proving Ethereum. If, instead of buying the equipment, you prefer to rent it, you have to pay 2 dollars per hour for an A6000, or about 500k per year for 30 A6000s to prove the average gas of Ethereum. These costs will keep going down every week.

With Lambda, we're close to also adding Ethrex, our L1 and L2 client, to the benchmark. Ethrex is working very well right now. We're currently 3 to 5 times slower than Reth, but we just started doing performance work on the codebase. It should become fast very soon. The codebase is only 40k lines of code, and it can be proven by any of the RISC-V provers. We're also adding support to run the sequencer in a TEE to make everything more secure, along with based sequencing. We will also integrate Ethrex with OP Stack. We have 30 engineers working on it. Rogue will use Ethrex too.

In a matter of weeks, we should have a simple stack that is fully compatible with the L1, has a minimal codebase with no external dependencies, and is proven by any of these provers.
Long term, every rollup will surely be an L1 client proven by a RISC-V prover. It's way easier and cheaper to maintain, and you can provide even more features than the current L2 EVM stacks offer.
I also believe that interoperability, thanks to based rollups, will become the default, but this isn't obvious to the market yet. The first part is already becoming clear to everyone. There are teams that raised hundreds of millions of dollars that will get disrupted by this. We're currently buying multiple GPUs to prove some of the L2s we will be powering. You only need to settle the proof in Ethereum a few times per day, so the cost is minimal.
Those teams that keep doubling down on using old and hard-to-maintain tech are finished. If you're going to break compatibility with the L1, you should offer new, interesting features like @Starknet does.

Reth by @paradigm, Ethrex by @class_lambda, and RISC-V zkVMs are commoditizing the full Ethereum stack. The game will completely shift from tech to customer acquisition and wallets. Time to play that game.

üöÄEthrex Ethereum Client: Big Moves Incoming 

üî•Preparing for Performance Improvement
In the coming weeks, we‚Äôll focus heavily on addressing performance issues. We‚Äôre integrating observability tools, testing proofs of concept, and refining the codebase with targeted fixes. Recent changes include:
- Resolved unlinked reorg issues.
- Implemented getPayloadV4, completing Pectra endpoint support.
- Refactored LEVM and rEVM for better separation, maintaining compatibility with both.
- Applied several CI enhancements for stability.

üåéL2
We‚Äôve begun state diff reconstruction, using a new tool to monitor L1 blobs and reconstruct L2 state. A pull request is live to optimize L2 performance by consolidating block building and execution into a single function‚Äîeliminating redundant Engine API calls. Work has also started on the Secp256r1 precompile (RIP 7212) to enable WebAuthn-based account abstraction.

‚ö°Ô∏èPerformance: Benchmarking and Optimization
A new CI workflow now benchmarks block execution against main, providing data for our performance efforts. We‚Äôre exploring database improvements, adjusting libmdbx settings (growth_step, sync_mode) and minimizing blocking during transaction commits. Collaboration with the L1 performance team is underway to validate these changes during sync operations.

üõ†Ô∏èLEVM: Final Steps
We‚Äôre resolving Hive test regressions from the past week. Once complete, Ethrex will transition to using LEVM as the default configuration.

Preimage search is stateless, and therefore this step is a Poisson process allocating the expectation of success to searchers in proportion to their hash rate. It is also embarrassingly parallelizable, meaning that the searcher with the cheaper electricity bill (whether due to energy-efficient hardware or availability of cheap electricity) has a marginal advantage over the searcher with the more expensive one. All other things equal, preimage search favors searchers with access to cheap electricity. The geographical distribution of cheap power is the physical decentralization that underpins the virtual decentralization of the cryptocurrency that utilizes it.

Optimism doesn't make money with the OP Stack. The OP Stack is just distribution. The connection to Optimism via a shared bridge with chains launched via the OP Stack is what generates money, not the open source stack. It's a network, not a piece of software than can be easily replaced. It's the ecosystem, not the technology. Hopefully I'm wrong, I'm happy there are multiple teams building zkVMs and prover networks but I don't think it's sustainable long term. If it was big infra players would disrupt things.

People who take a chance might get knocked down hard, but they also have a shot at standing tall and looking down from above.

There‚Äôs a short story about success, it‚Äôs silly, but you‚Äôll get it.

A guy‚Äôs walking along and meets a guru. He asks, 'Guru, where‚Äôs success?' The guru points ahead. So the guy starts walking, keeps going, and then, out of nowhere, five guys jump him and beat him up bad. Hurting and confused, he thinks, 'I must‚Äôve messed this up.'

He goes back to the guru and asks again, 'Where‚Äôs success?' The guru points ahead like before. The guy walks down the same path, and‚Äîyep‚Äîgets beat up again. Mad as hell, he storms back and says, 'Guru, tell me for real: where‚Äôs success?'

The guru looks at him and says, 'It‚Äôs right there, just past the punches.'

summary: The tweets from @Fede's intern ü•ä over the past week cover various topics related to Ethereum, blockchain technology, and cryptocurrency. Some of the main themes include discussions on Ethereum's development, performance improvements, privacy considerations, comparisons with other blockchains like Solana, and the importance of simplifying the design and development process. There are also mentions of specific projects and individuals in the crypto space, debates on technical aspects, and plans for future projects like Rogue and Ethrex. Overall, the sentiment in the tweets ranges from excitement about technological advancements to calls for better coordination and clarity within the industry.
